info.name: SnapGeo OCR API
info.description:
# SnapGeo OCR - GPS Coordinate Extraction Service

**Advanced OCR service that extracts GPS coordinates from images with confidence scoring**

## üéØ Overview
SnapGeo OCR is a production-ready FastAPI microservice that extracts GPS coordinates from images containing GPS overlays. Using advanced Tesseract OCR processing with 40+ configurations, it achieves **88.9% success rate** on challenging GPS overlay images.

## ‚ú® Key Features
- **üéØ High Accuracy**: 88.9% success rate on challenging GPS overlay images
- **üß† Smart Processing**: Multi-stage OCR with fragment reconstruction
- **üìä Confidence Scoring**: Quality assessment for each coordinate extraction
- **‚ö° Fast Processing**: 2-7 seconds per image
- **üåç Geographic Context**: Indonesian location mapping and validation

## üìä Confidence Levels
- **Very High (0.90+)**: Production ready - Direct usage
- **High (0.80-0.89)**: Highly reliable - Safe for most cases
- **Medium (0.60-0.79)**: Good quality - Generally reliable
- **Low (<0.60)**: Use with caution - Manual review needed

## üîó Documentation
- **Swagger UI**: https://snapgeo-ocr.onrender.com/docs
- **ReDoc**: https://snapgeo-ocr.onrender.com/redoc
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/your-username/snapgeo-ocr

## üìû Support
- **Health Check**: Use the Health Check folder to verify service status
- **API Testing**: Use OCR Processing folder for coordinate extraction
- **Examples**: Check the Example Responses folder for expected outputs

formdata.description: Upload an image file containing GPS overlay (JPG, JPEG, PNG)

request.description:
**Extract GPS coordinates from images with GPS overlays**

## üì§ Request
- **Method**: POST
- **Content-Type**: multipart/form-data
- **File Parameter**: `file` (required)
- **Supported Formats**: JPG, JPEG, PNG
- **Max File Size**: 10MB (configurable)

## üì• Response
- **Success**: GPS coordinates with confidence scoring
- **Processing Time**: 2-7 seconds depending on image quality
- **Confidence Score**: 0.0-1.0 (higher is better)

## üß™ Testing Instructions
1. Click "Select Files" in the file parameter
2. Choose an image with GPS overlay (bottom-right corner)
3. Send the request
4. Check the confidence score in the response
5. Verify coordinates are within Indonesian bounds (-11¬∞ to -1¬∞S, 95¬∞ to 141¬∞E)

## üìä Expected Success Rates
- **Perfect Quality**: ~95% success rate
- **Good Quality**: ~85% success rate
- **Poor Quality**: ~70% success rate

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Notes
- GPS overlays should be in bottom-right corner
- Processing time varies by image quality
- Check confidence score before using coordinates
- Use coordinates with confidence ‚â• 0.8 for production

response.name: ‚úÖ High Confidence Success
response.body:
{
  "raw_text": "7¬∞33'15.8\"S 110¬∞38'38.7\"E\nSpeed: 0.0km/h\nAltitude: 125.3msnm\nIndex number: 42",
  "latitude": -7.55492507,

    "explanation": "Coordinates reconstructed from detected fragments"
  },
  "ocr_method": "ultra_crop2_ultra_coords"
}

formdata.description: Upload multiple images for batch testing

request.description:
**Batch testing endpoint for multiple images**

## üîÑ Batch Testing Workflow
1. Use this request to test multiple images sequentially
2. Check the test results tab for success/failure status
3. Monitor confidence scores across different images
4. Analyze patterns in success rates

## üìä What to Monitor
- **Success Rate**: Percentage of successful extractions
- **Confidence Distribution**: How many high/medium/low confidence results
- **Processing Time**: Variation based on image quality
- **Error Patterns**: Common failure modes

## üß™ Testing Strategy
1. **Perfect Quality Images**: Should achieve 0.90+ confidence
2. **Good Quality Images**: Should achieve 0.80+ confidence
3. **Poor Quality Images**: May achieve 0.60+ confidence
4. **Very Poor Images**: May fail or achieve <0.60 confidence

## üí° Tips
- Run this request multiple times with different images
- Use the Collection Runner for automated batch testing
- Check the console logs for detailed confidence information
- Compare results across different image qualities

item.description:
**GPS Coordinate Extraction Endpoints**

This folder contains requests for extracting GPS coordinates from images with GPS overlays. The SnapGeo OCR service uses advanced multi-stage processing to achieve high accuracy rates.

## üéØ Processing Pipeline
1. **Image Upload**: Accepts JPG, JPEG, PNG files
2. **Multi-Stage OCR**: 40+ Tesseract configurations
3. **Fragment Reconstruction**: Rebuilds coordinates from partial OCR
4. **Pattern Matching**: Intelligent coordinate pattern detection
5. **Confidence Scoring**: Quality assessment of extraction method

## üìä Success Rates
- **Overall**: 88.9% success rate on challenging images
- **High Confidence (‚â•0.8)**: 66.7% of successful extractions
- **Processing Time**: 2-7 seconds per image

## üß™ Testing Tips
- Use images with GPS overlays in bottom-right corner
- Test with various image qualities (perfect to poor)
- Check confidence scores before using coordinates
- Monitor processing times for performance analysis

request.description:
**Check the health status of the SnapGeo OCR service**

## üéØ Purpose
- Verify that the service is running and responsive
- Monitor service availability for load balancers
- Quick connectivity test before processing images
- Performance monitoring (response time)

## ‚úÖ Expected Response
```json
{
  "status": "healthy"
}
```

## üîç What This Checks
- **Service Availability**: FastAPI server is running
- **Basic Functionality**: HTTP endpoints are responding
- **Response Time**: Service performance indicator
- **Load Balancer Ready**: Endpoint for health monitoring

## üö® Troubleshooting
- **Timeout**: Service may be starting up (wait 30-60 seconds)
- **Connection Error**: Check if service is deployed and accessible
- **Slow Response**: Service may be under heavy load

## üí° Usage Tips
- Run this before any OCR processing requests
- Use for monitoring service availability
- Include in automated health check systems
- Good for testing connectivity and authentication

request.description:
**Wake up the Render service from sleep (Free Tier Optimization)**

## üéØ Purpose
Render's free tier puts services to sleep after 15 minutes of inactivity. This request wakes up the service before batch processing to avoid long delays on OCR requests.

## ‚è∞ Expected Behavior
- **First Request (Cold Start)**: 20-30 seconds response time
- **Service Warm-up**: 2-3 seconds for full initialization
- **Subsequent Requests**: <1 second response time

## üî• Warm-up Strategy
1. **Health Check**: Ping the service to wake it up
2. **Wait Period**: Allow 2-3 seconds for full initialization
3. **Ready for Processing**: OCR requests will be fast

## üìä Performance Impact
- **Without Warm-up**: Each OCR request has potential 20-30s delay
- **With Warm-up**: Only first health check is slow, all OCR requests are fast
- **Time Savings**: Significant for batch processing multiple images

## üí° Usage Tips
- **Always run this first** before OCR processing
- **Wait for completion** before starting OCR requests
- **Monitor console logs** for wake-up status
- **Use in Collection Runner** as first step in workflows

## üîÑ Recommended Workflow
1. Run this wake-up request
2. Wait for ‚úÖ confirmation in console
3. Proceed with OCR processing requests
4. Enjoy fast response times!

## üö® Free Tier Notes
- Service sleeps after 15 minutes of inactivity
- Wake-up is required only after sleep period
- No cost optimization needed for paid tiers

exec: pm.test("Service is healthy and ready", function () {
console.log('üöÄ Service is fully warmed up and ready!');
console.log('‚úÖ You can now proceed with OCR processing');
console.log('‚è∞ Service may need a bit more time to warm up');
console.log('üîÑ Consider waiting 5-10 more seconds before OCR requests');

request.description:
**Verify the service is fully warmed up and ready for OCR processing**

## üéØ Purpose
Double-check that the service is fully initialized and ready for fast OCR processing after wake-up.

## ‚úÖ Readiness Indicators
- **Response Time**: <1-3 seconds (service is warm)
- **Status**: "healthy" response
- **Global Flag**: service_warm = true

## üìä Performance Verification
- **Fast Response (<1s)**: Service fully ready
- **Medium Response (1-3s)**: Service warming up, almost ready
- **Slow Response (>5s)**: May need additional time

## üîÑ Next Steps
After this verification passes:
1. ‚úÖ Service is ready for OCR processing
2. üöÄ All OCR requests will be fast
3. üìä No more cold start delays

## üí° Optional Step
This verification is optional but recommended for:
- **Batch Processing**: Ensure optimal performance
- **Time-Critical Applications**: Confirm readiness
- **Performance Testing**: Baseline measurement

console.log('3. All requests will now be fast (<3 seconds)');

request.description:
**Complete warm-up workflow - Service is ready for production use**

## üéâ Workflow Summary
This completes the 3-step warm-up process:
1. ‚úÖ **Wake Up Service**: Initial cold start (20-30s)
2. ‚úÖ **Verify Ready**: Confirm fast response (<3s)
3. ‚úÖ **Production Ready**: All subsequent requests will be fast

## üöÄ Performance Benefits
- **Eliminated Cold Starts**: No more 20-30 second delays
- **Consistent Performance**: All OCR requests now <5 seconds
- **Batch Processing Ready**: Optimal for multiple images
- **Production Performance**: On free tier!

## üìä Expected Results After Warm-up
- **Health Check**: <1 second response
- **OCR Processing**: 2-7 seconds (based on image quality)
- **Batch Processing**: Consistent timing across requests
- **No Interruptions**: Service stays warm during active use

## üîÑ When to Re-run Warm-up
- **After 15+ minutes of inactivity**: Service may sleep again
- **First request of the day**: Cold start likely
- **Slow OCR responses**: Indicates service may have slept
- **Before important demos**: Ensure optimal performance

## üí° Automation Tips
- **Collection Runner**: Include this as first step
- **Scheduled Requests**: Keep service warm with periodic pings
- **Monitoring**: Set up alerts for response time increases
- **Team Workflow**: Document this process for team members

item.description:
**Service Warm-up Workflow for Render Free Tier**

Optimized workflow to eliminate cold start delays on Render's free tier. This folder contains a strategic 3-step process to ensure optimal performance without upgrading to paid plans.

## üéØ Problem: Render Free Tier Cold Starts
- **Service Sleep**: After 15 minutes of inactivity
- **Wake-up Time**: 20-30 seconds for first request
- **Impact**: Poor user experience, especially for batch processing

## üî• Solution: Smart Warm-up Strategy

### Step 1: Wake Up Service (20-30s)
- Ping health endpoint to trigger wake-up
- Monitor wake-up time and status
- Set global flags for workflow tracking

### Step 2: Verify Service Ready (<3s)
- Confirm service is fully initialized
- Validate fast response times
- Ensure readiness for OCR processing

### Step 3: Production Ready
- Service now responds in <1 second
- OCR processing optimized (2-7s per image)
- Batch processing without delays

## üìä Performance Impact

### Without Warm-up:
- **Each OCR Request**: Potential 20-30s delay
- **Batch of 10 Images**: Up to 5 minutes of cold start delays
- **User Experience**: Poor, unpredictable timing

### With Warm-up:
- **Initial Health Check**: 20-30s (one time)
- **All OCR Requests**: 2-7s (consistent)
- **Batch of 10 Images**: Predictable, fast processing
- **User Experience**: Production-quality performance

## üîÑ Recommended Usage

### Manual Testing:
1. Run "1. Wake Up Service" first
2. Wait for ‚úÖ confirmation
3. Proceed with OCR processing

### Batch Processing:
1. Use Collection Runner
2. Include warm-up as first requests
3. Run OCR requests after warm-up

### Team Workflow:
1. Document this process for team
2. Always warm up before demos
3. Monitor for sleep periods (15+ min inactivity)

## üí° Pro Tips
- **Keep Service Warm**: Ping every 10-14 minutes during active work
- **Monitor Response Times**: >10s indicates service may be sleeping
- **Batch Optimization**: Warm up once, process multiple images
- **No Cost**: This strategy works perfectly on free tier

## üö® When Service Sleeps Again
- **After 15+ minutes** of no requests
- **First request of the day**
- **Long breaks** between processing sessions
- **Solution**: Re-run this warm-up workflow

This warm-up strategy gives you **production-level performance on Render's free tier!** üöÄ

console.log('üéØ Goal: Eliminate cold start delays for OCR processing');

request.description:

- **Authentication**: Security requirements (when implemented)
- **Examples**: Sample requests and responses

## üìñ Alternative Documentation

## üß™ Interactive API Documentation
This opens the Swagger UI interface where you can:

- **Browse Endpoints**: View all available API endpoints
- **Test Requests**: Make actual API calls directly from the browser

## üéØ Features

## üí° Usage Tips

- Useful for debugging and troubleshooting

Open {{base_url}}/docs in your browser for the full interactive experience.

**Access the clean ReDoc API documentation**

## üìñ Clean API Documentation
ReDoc provides a clean, readable format for API documentation:

- **Clean Layout**: Easy-to-read documentation format

## üéØ Best For

- **Team Sharing**: Clean format for stakeholder reviews
- **Documentation Export**: Print-friendly API reference

## üîó Direct Access
Open {{base_url}}/redoc in your browser for the clean documentation view.

This folder provides access to various forms of API documentation for the SnapGeo OCR service.

## üìö Documentation Types

### ‚öôÔ∏è Machine-Readable (OpenAPI)

## üõ† Usage Scenarios

item.name: üß™ Example Responses

request.description:
**Example response for perfect quality GPS overlay image**

## üìä Perfect Quality Characteristics
- **Image Quality**: Crystal clear GPS overlay text
- **Processing Method**: Direct OCR without enhancement
- **Confidence Score**: 0.95 (very_high)
- **Processing Time**: ~2 seconds

## ‚úÖ Expected Results
```json
{
  "latitude": -6.26891158,
  "longitude": 107.25537723,
  "confidence": {
    "score": 0.95,
    "level": "very_high",
    "method": "direct_ocr",
    "explanation": "Coordinates found directly in OCR text without reconstruction"
  },
  "raw_text": "6¬∞16'8.3\"S 107¬∞15'19.4\"E",
  "ocr_method": "region_config_1"
}
```

## üéØ Use Cases
- **Production Systems**: Safe for automated processing
- **Navigation Apps**: High precision for routing
- **Mapping Services**: Reliable coordinate data
- **Analytics**: Trusted location data

**Note**: This is a mock endpoint for documentation. Use the actual `/ocr` endpoint for processing.

- **Processing Method**: Fragment reconstruction
- **Confidence Score**: 0.75 (medium_high)
- **Processing Time**: ~4-5 seconds

## ‚úÖ Expected Results
```json
{
  "latitude": -7.55492507,
  "longitude": 110.64424782,
  "confidence": {
    "score": 0.75,
    "level": "medium_high",
    "method": "enhanced_ocr",
    "explanation": "Coordinates extracted using enhanced OCR processing"
  },
  "latitude_reconstructed": true,
  "longitude_reconstructed": false
}
```

## ‚ö†Ô∏è Usage Considerations
- **Validation Recommended**: Consider additional verification
- **Business Logic**: Apply confidence thresholds
- **User Confirmation**: May require user review
- **Fallback Options**: Have alternative data sources

**Note**: This is a mock endpoint for documentation. Use the actual `/ocr` endpoint for processing.

request.description:
**Example response when GPS coordinates cannot be extracted**

## ‚ùå Failure Scenarios
- **No GPS Overlay**: Image doesn't contain GPS information
- **Poor Image Quality**: Text too blurred or corrupted
- **Unsupported Format**: Non-standard GPS overlay format
- **Processing Error**: Technical issues during OCR

## üìÑ Error Response Format
```json
{
  "error": "GPS coordinates not found, but extracted other location metadata",
  "location_info": ["Jakarta", "Jawa Barat", "Indonesia"],
  "raw_text": "Street view image without GPS overlay\nLocation: Jakarta"
}
```

## üîß Error Handling
- **HTTP Status**: 422 (Unprocessable Entity)
- **Graceful Degradation**: Provide location info when available
- **User Feedback**: Clear error messages
- **Retry Logic**: May succeed with different processing

## üí° Troubleshooting
- **Check Image Quality**: Ensure GPS overlay is visible
- **Verify Format**: Use JPG, JPEG, or PNG
- **Try Different Images**: Some formats work better
- **Contact Support**: For persistent issues

**Note**: This is a mock endpoint for documentation. Use the actual `/ocr` endpoint for processing.

response.name: Failed Extraction Response

item.description:
**Example API Responses**

This folder contains example responses for different scenarios to help developers understand the expected API behavior.

## üìä Response Categories

### ‚úÖ Success Responses
- **Perfect Quality**: Very high confidence (0.90+)
- **Good Quality**: High confidence (0.80-0.89)
- **Medium Quality**: Medium confidence (0.60-0.79)

### ‚ö†Ô∏è Partial Success
- **Low Quality**: Low confidence (<0.60)
- **Geographic Estimation**: Location-based coordinates

### ‚ùå Error Responses
- **No Coordinates**: GPS overlay not found
- **Invalid Format**: Unsupported file type
- **Processing Error**: Technical failures

## üéØ Usage
- **Development**: Understand response structures
- **Testing**: Expected behavior for different scenarios
- **Integration**: Error handling patterns
- **Documentation**: Share examples with team

**Note**: These are example/mock endpoints for documentation purposes. Use the actual `/ocr` endpoint for processing real images.
